207886: Urza's Rage.author: Cyberium
207886: Urza's Rage.text_parsed:
Banefire = cost 4 mana for 3 damage, sorcery speed, and cannot be countered/prevented at 6+ mana.

Urza's Rage = cost 3 mana for 3 damage, instant speed, cannot be countered, and cannot be prevented at 12 mana.

While Rage lacks variability in terms of how much damage you do or how much mana you spend, it's a solid card. If you have two Banefire in hand, you may be able to kill your opponent in two turns but it would leave you tapped out, whereas Urza's would allow you open mana to react should opponent plays something dangerous. Don't forget Urza's Rage can't be countered right from start.

Banefire for straight burn, but Urza's Rage is probably a better choice for counter-burn variant as a finisher.

207886: Urza's Rage.author: Salient
207886: Urza's Rage.text_parsed:
Yep, this is as Mythic as it gets. Perfect place to reprint it, too. Mythic rares should be (1) iconic, defining the spirit of the set by portraying some really important character or item or event, (2) unique or nearly unique, in some gameplay-defining way, and (3) absurdly mana-overcosted, so that they are bombs in draft and fun to play in casual, but not the new $100 must-have-to-play-in-constructed-tournaments card.

Mythic cards don't need to be good; they need to be awesome. And, Urza's Rage is a perfect example of a not-good awesome card: an effective CMC of 12 is not good, but 10 uncounterable unpreventable damage is awesome.

Three uncounterable unpreventable damage for three mana isn't bad, but personally I'm more terrified of the fact that if you make Urza mad he will channel of HAAATE at you at instant speed.

Don't make that dude angry. You won't like what he does with his four Black Lotuses when he's angry...
207886: Urza's Rage.text_posted:

Mythic rares should be (1) iconic, defining the spirit of the set by portraying some really important character or item or event, (2) unique or nearly unique, in some gameplay-defining way, and (3) absurdly mana-overcosted, so that they are bombs in draft and fun to play in casual, but not the new $100 must-have-to-play-in-constructed-tournaments card.

Mythic cards don't need to be [i]good[/i]; they need to be [i]awesome[/i]. And, Urza's Rage is a perfect example of a not-good awesome card: an effective CMC of 12 is not good, but 10 uncounterable unpreventable damage is awesome.

Three uncounterable unpreventable damage for three mana isn't bad, but personally I'm more terrified of the fact that [i]if you make Urza mad he will channel [10][R][R] of HAAATE at you at instant speed.[/i]

Don't make that dude angry. You won't like what he does with his four Black Lotuses when he's angry...

207887: Yavimaya Elder.author: humor_love
207887: Yavimaya Elder.text_parsed:
There are a lot of complaints here that a creature can't deal damage while being sacrificed (about the "M10 rule changes").

The M10 "rule changes" were actually a reversion to the way that Magic was originally played. I don't know precisely when it happened, but around '99 or '00 (maybe a year or two before), the rules were changed so that creatures can deal combat damage despite being destroyed before the 'combat damage dealing' step. It created a combat damage "stack", so that a creature's 'attack' hung in the air and took effect even if the creature wasn't actually there.

Originally, however, a creature's sword or claws or teeth were not allowed to deal damage if they weren't actually around. This is what makes the card Smite actually quite potent and powerful; especially in a color in which blockers are fairly easy to come by. There are probably a number of other cards which were originally designed with the 'combat damage stack' not being a reality.

207888: Phyrexian Processor.author: EvilCleavage
207888: Phyrexian Processor.text_parsed: I was the first person in my town of Hanford, CA to get this duel deck!! The vendor was filling the shelves at our super wal-mart and asked me if I wanted to check out this new magic product that had come out. I said sure and he handed me this! I seriously looked at it and had to look twice when I saw that phyrexian negator was on the front! And I had to get it when I saw it said it had ten rares in it! When I got home I opened it and was oh so pleasantly surprised when I saw all the old school cards that were in it! I lost all of my cards back about ten years ago, and to make a long story short I was so happy to get all these great cards! And the coalition deck has 3 of the dragons from invasion! Man this is a great deal to get some more good suicide black cards and it has a bunch of amazing artifacts in it including this card above which could seriously win you the game, phyrexian colossus, phyrexian plaguelord, phyrexian gargantua etc. And the coalition deck has a lot of mana accelerator creatures and a bunch of other good stuff! I would recommend this box set for sure, ESPECIALLY for someone like me that got out of touch from magic for a long time (and I quit playing right after the urza block) and wants to get back into it, or a beginner or even someone that just wants to double up on a bunch of these great cards.

207888: Phyrexian Processor.author: Aquillion
207888: Phyrexian Processor.text_parsed:
The problem with a lot of the combos people are proposing is this:

If you can play and use this card and then land an attack with the resulting creature, you've probably won anyway. That's not the weakness this card has.

The big weaknesses here are artifact destruction and direct damage (which can kill you instantly if you spend too much life.) It doesn't really matter if you have some plan to gain back the life spend to play it, because generally by the time you're benefiting from that, you could have just used your giant creatures to win the game already.
207888: Phyrexian Processor.text_posted:
The problem with a lot of the combos people are proposing is this:

It doesn't really matter if you have some plan to gain back the life spend to play it, because generally by the time you're benefiting from that, you could have just used your giant creatures to win the game already.

207890: Armadillo Cloak.author: cissero
207890: Armadillo Cloak.text_parsed:
So I have a rules question. With the enchantment "Lifelink" it says, "Target creature gains lifelink", therefore the controller of the enchanted creature gains the life. However, with Armadillo Cloak, if I enchant an opponent's creature with it, do I (as the controller of the enchantment) gain the life?

I am under the impression that since the card says, "Whenever enchanted creature deals damage, YOU gain that much life" YOU = The controller of Armadillo Cloak.

Please help.

Thanks.
207890: Armadillo Cloak.text_posted:

However, with Armadillo Cloak, if I enchant an opponent's creature with it, do I (as the controller of the enchantment) gain the life?

207890: Armadillo Cloak.author: Quang
207890: Armadillo Cloak.text_parsed:
Yes, this card stacks with lifelink thus you get double lifegain.

An instance is Behemoth Sledge + this.

@brunsbr103: Not really. Behemoth Sledge stays in the field when your equipped creature dies but armadillo cloak goes with the creature when it dies. You only need to pay 3 mana to equip it so armadillo cloak is cheaper if you want to attack early. You can also enchant armadillo cloak on your opponent's creatures to render them useless when they're attacking, but not when blocking.

I personally love both of the cards <3

207890: Armadillo Cloak.author: Zosk
207890: Armadillo Cloak.text_parsed:
There is always a risk involved when playing auras, since you can lose two of your cards for the price of one of your opponent's cards. So when using an aura, one must ask if the reward is worth the risk.

This is one of my buddy's favourite cards. I cannot count the number of games that have swung in his favour merely because I couldn't answer his cloaked creature.

If you are going to play an aura in your deck, you can't go wrong with Armadillo Cloak.

This new artwork is nice, but the original artwork is more humorous, which lends well the the ridiculous flavor.

207890: Armadillo Cloak.author: Bbone37
207890: Armadillo Cloak.text_parsed:
@BaneReckoning: Just so you are aware, this is a triggered ability, and it triggers when damage is dealt, not assigned. By that I mean, if your friend has a 20/20 avatar, and you are at 20, you enchant it with this, then he swings on his turn, you will die. It has to deal the damage for your triggered effect to trigger, and in this case you would be dead. Not saying it isn't a good idea to enchant an opponent's creature to mitigate some damage, but you have to first survive the damage in order to gain it back. hope this helps.

@mpitc ock: or is Behemoth sledge the equipment version of this?

as far as everyone else talking about lifelink, I am glad this is not "lifelink". as other stated, it stacks with itself and lifelink, and also works on others' creatures.

I'd say 4/5. A very powerful aura, but as an aura you need a creture and set yourself up for a 2-for-1. AT LEAST if you get to swing once with the damage dealt and life gained will make up for this potential card dissadvantage, imo.

207891: Phyrexian Negator.author: IshubarashI
207891: Phyrexian Negator.text_parsed:
This card is really too much of a gamble to use in the main deck. I played with a friends phyrexian deck earlier (loved it by the way, I'm definitely a black mage) and I used the totem, in combination with the colossus and one other creature to put them at an ultimatum (they only had 3 creatures to block with), they decided to pump one of their 1/1s to a 4/4 and block the negator, i still connected with 9 total damage but ended up sacrificing the negator and 3 swamps which hurt me in the long run. I might have won if I hadn't lost those lands

I honestly like this card, and I imagine it was a powerhouse against control/combo decks back in the day. 10 total p/t for 3 mana, and in a color that can ritual the monstrosity out on the first turn. But this dude needs to stay in the sideboard until it's safe to come out. He's just too risky nowadays.

207891: Phyrexian Negator.author: blurrymadness
207891: Phyrexian Negator.text_parsed:
I realized that this guy is hideously effective with double-strike. in R/B you can do the standard Dark Rit play T1, then if they block T2 you drop a double cleave => 7-9 damage to their face, no loss of permanents for you, and they lost a creature in the process. Assault Strobe gives you a 1-mana (and thus less risky for permanents) way to do the same thing if you have a blood crypt out.

Ran next to unearth, dark rit, dakmor salvage, and some other "3 cmc matters" cards, this may be a neat archtype. Hypnotic Specter fits with the double-strike as well; I'm sure there are other neat 3 CMC or less cards that fit with this as well, such as skittering horror.

209111: Darigaaz, the Igniter.author: DarthParallax
209111: Darigaaz, the Igniter.text_parsed:
Primordial Dragon EDH Review 4/5: Darigaaz, the Igniter

Darigaaz is awesome. He's a base-red Dragon. A lot of the cards you might want if you're just a natural Dragon fan, make perfect sense in a Darigaaz deck. The first card I'm going to suggest is Hellkite Overlord.

If you've been following my other Primordial Dragon Reviews, you'll know the next cards I'm going to say ought to go into your deck: Darigaaz's Charm, Darigaaz's Attendant, and Darigaaz's Caldera.

There's two more cards I'd like to mention now that I would apply to all 5 Primordial EDH decks with an obvious caveat on one: Coalition Relic and Savage Lands (really I mean this cycle must be used). I was going back and forth whether or not flavorfully Alara Lands were alright for Dominarian Dragons....but then I realized that's just silly. Without the Tri-Lands, your deck is weaker. With them, not only is it stronger, but it's really no less Vorthos than it was before. I *do* want to avoid Esper Artifacts for Dromar, but other than that, there are plenty of Grixis, Jund, Bant, and Naya cards that seem to be just good fits for decks in general and maybe even good fits for the decks' strategies. (Knotvine Mystic in Rith might be like Sol Ring on a stick for the mana it can produce?) Arcane Sanctum isn't specifically artifacty, so there's no reason to screw poor Dromar by disallowing his triple land on flavor reasons.

Back to Darigaaz. I have wierd ideas about Planeswalkers and wouldn't use 4 Sarkhan Vol in a 60-card deck. I mean I wouldn't even use 2 Jace, the Mind Sculptor if I was DELIBERATELY building Caw-Blade but I would use 1. I don't think an EDH deck should include both Sarkhan, the Mad and Sarkhan Vol and I'd apply that to other 'Walkers as well. But it's clear to me that either one of the Sarkhan Planeswalker cards would be great for Darigaaz, because he's in the Colors of Jund and Jund stuff tends to be BAMF. Go ahead and throw Lavalanche in there, too. I haven't built very many Jund decks but you should be good at making and breaking Lands.

Ultimately, Darigaaz's deck should be Violent. Don't build the deck a Magic Pro Tour Top 8 Duelist would. Build the Deck the Incredible Hulk would run against a thousand aliens, hundreds of heroes and an arch demigod villain. At once.

I try to specify fewer cards for Darigaaz than anyone else because he's just more sledgehammer than scalpel by personality- you wanna grief hands? fine grief hands. you wanna grief lands? fine grief lands. you wanna ramp and destroy the battlefield? fine ramp and destroy the battlefield. Primeval Titan and Ruination I could both see in the same Darigaaz Deck. The most important question you need to ask when building Darigaaz is this:

How many times do you get to say
"DARIGAAZ SMASH!" ?

PS: Sever the Bloodline should be mentioned either her or under Crosis for dealing with Rith's Tokens. That's all.

209114: Harrow.author: TongueSlicer
209114: Harrow.text_parsed:
As you cast harrow could you target a terramorphic expanse, for harrow's additional cost, and then sacrifice it using terramorphic's expanse own ability?
Or harrow would be countered that way?
209114: Harrow.text_posted:
As you cast harrow could you target a [autocard]terramorphic expanse[/autocard], for harrow's additional cost, and then sacrifice it using terramorphic's expanse own ability?
Or harrow would be countered that way?

209114: Harrow.author: Minus_Prime
209114: Harrow.text_parsed:
@TongueSlicer:

You can't do that. Harrow doesn't sac a target land upon resolution. Terramorphic Expanse would be sacrificed immediately as part of Harrow's casting cost. Paying the casting cost of a spell can't be interrupted, therefore you couldn't tap Terramorphic Expanse for its land search ability.

If T.E. read "when this card is sacrificed" or "when this card is put into a graveyard from play" or something, then you could do what you're asking. As it stands T.E. has to tap and sacrifice itself to activate its land search ability, which is a payment separate from being sacrificed to pay for Harrow.

Assuming you could interrupt the casting cost of Harrow, when it came time to pay it you would have to sacrifice a different land, or else the spell would be countered.
209114: Harrow.text_posted:
@TongueSlicer:

You can't do that. Harrow doesn't sac a target land upon resolution. Terramorphic Expanse would be sacrificed immediately as part of Harrow's casting cost. Paying the casting cost of a spell can't be interrupted, therefore you couldn't tap Terramorphic Expanse for its land search ability.

If T.E. read "when this card is sacrificed" or "when this card is put into a graveyard from play" or something, then you could do what you're asking. As it stands T.E. has to tap and sacrifice itself to activate its land search ability, which is a payment separate from being sacrificed to pay for Harrow.

Assuming you [i]could[/i] interrupt the casting cost of Harrow, when it came time to pay it you would have to sacrifice a different land, or else the spell would be countered.

209114: Harrow.author: OlvynChuru
209114: Harrow.text_parsed:
@shocker300

Just because Harrow doesn't do too well against blue doesn't mean it's a bad card. Last time I checked, some decks aren't blue.

One little trick you can do with Harrow in a green-blue deck is to make people think that you can't counter their spells when, because of Harrow, you can. For example, lets say you have Harrow and Cancel in your hand. You have three forests and one island untapped. The opponent might think that you can't counter their game-changing creature, so they cast it. In response, you cast Harrow, search for enough islands that you can cast Cancel, then cast it.

209121: Treva, the Renewer.author: DarthParallax
209121: Treva, the Renewer.text_parsed:
Primordial Dragons EDH Review 1/5: Treva, the Renewer

The cycle of Invasion Dragons (Treva, Dromar, Crosis, Darigaaz, and Rith) are interesting options for EDH play. Unlike the Elder Dragons, there is more than 1 playable card, and none of them are really brutal/broken (though Rith is easily the best). What's good about them is they are all chunky fliers, which means they'll never be un-relevant for combat once you slap any staple Equipments on them, and they are Allied Colored, which makes decks easier to plan and build. Lands and Mana Artifacts are more available for ally colors than for Enemy colors, and the Enemy Lands that do exist are harder to afford because they're *always* rare.

For Treva, both her colors and her ability point very sharply towards a lifegain deck. I'd say a good Treva deck wants to use fewer Blue cards than Green/White cards, and try to gain as much life as possible. I don't know if her permanent-counting ability looks at just your cards or the whole table's cards, but either way you shouldn't have a problem after reading a few Rith lists that Doubling Season and Tokens are simply the best way to go.

To make Treva feel much different than playing Rith though, I'd like to be more controlling and try to build a "Pillowfort" I can hide behind rather than rush out armies. Bant is the colors of Heroes, and trading Red for Blue can give us excellent Aura manipulation. I think Rafiq of the Many is a bit cheap to use as a General, but he's an awesome battlefield Champion to put in your 99. I've been inspired by the way the Guild Legends were designed for Ravnica: City of Guilds block to always include an additional Legendary creature in the exact color identity of my Commander to serve as a back-up 'Hero/Champion', and there's no denying Rafiq is one of the best go-to options for {G}{W}{U}.


Commander: Treva, the Renewer
Champion: Rafiq of the Many
Theme: Enchantments, Lifegain, Exalted

Battlegrace Angel, Stoic Angel, and Sublime Archangel are good picks to support the Exalted Rafiq and the tokens you'll be making with Treva's ability. I'm not going to write out a whole list but just gently suggest the kinda-sorta direction I'd want to take this Legend in.

I also think nowhere other than Treva will you have more reason to play Levitation, a Blue spell that really wants you to play tokens. I like the idea of giving an army flying, but it doesn't usually feel practical compared to other options you have. Rith in particular scoffs at Flying because she'd rather just have Haste anyway. I think this is a great place where you can use Treva's third color to make your deck play really differently from the ho-hum ''usual'' Green-White decks. It's Selesnya week on various MTG sites, and Green-White plays SO well together that Green-White-Red and Green-White-Black and Green-White-Blue really do feel close to the same: they're probably all token decks, some exploiting enters-the-battlefield abilities, some just being huge dorky armies. Usually, Huge Dorky Armies don't FLY, though. Cathar's Crusade + Levitation would be my pick for fighting Kaalia in her own element: Having epic clashes on the battlefield- or in the skies over the battlefield! I'd say Kaalia should want to kill and trade as much as possible and then Liliana everyone's everything out, while Treva should play the Good Guy and try to protect all of her allies with Avacyn and Elspeth, thwarting the Zombies plan.

For the same reason I don't think Rafiq should be your Commander, I don't think Felidar Sovereign is a nice card to play in EDH. It's just too Spikey, and Spikeyness tends to go against the spirit of the format. If you enjoy both EDH and Spikeyness, then I think Archenemy is EXACTLY what you're looking for- use Felidar Soveriegn THERE, if you're the villain, but otherwise avoid him if you can.

209128: Order of Yawgmoth.author: MattLynn
209128: Order of Yawgmoth.text_parsed:
I'm ridiculous for saying this, but this is more of a discard sure bet vs ol' Hypnotic. Yes, random discard is insane, but a deck oriented towards hand death find out later in a game that discard is discard: people's hands tend to be smaller later in a game. Just don't forget Ghastlord of Fugue, Raven's Crime, and Liliana of the Veil. Historically, a deck built like that in Magic prehistoric days would also have Minion of Leshrac and/or Demonic Hordes.

I feel that Blight, Nettlevine Blight, Rain of Tears, Strip Mine, etc are land death, yes, but help hand destruction soooo much. Kinda like how players using Rafiq the Many would typically like Silent Arbiter.

209129: Phyrexian Ghoul.author: MechaKraken
209129: Phyrexian Ghoul.text_parsed:
Believe it or not, this guy can actually be part of an infinite damage combo.

Simply pair him up with Rooftop Storm and a Gravecrawler .

Cast Phyrexian Ghoul first (so your opponent will not know what you are up to, and believe you are merely playing a chump blocker). The ghoul will have summoning sickness, so coyly wait until your next turn to proceed further with the combo.

Now on your next turn, play Rooftop Storm. All zombie creature spells are now free to cast. Play Gravecrawler, then use Phyrexian Ghoul's ability to sacrifice Gravecrawler and get a +2/+2 counter. Since Rooftop Storm is in play, you don't have to pay the mana to return Gravecrawler from the graveyard to the battlefield, so go ahead and do it. The Gravecrawler can now be sacrificed AGAIN, to power up Phyrexian Ghoul further!

Keep rinsing and repeating, until you have a vastly powered Phyrexian Ghoul with more then enough damage to dispatch your opponent. Cast Artful Dodge and swing for the win.

209129: Phyrexian Ghoul.author: SinForSanity
209129: Phyrexian Ghoul.text_parsed:
Technically, the only difference between this card and Nantuko Husk is their creature types. From a player's perspective, though, Nantuko Husk will always have the better reputation because it was a staple in it's standard season. Phyrexian Ghoul just doesn't have the level of exposure that Nantuko Husk once had.

Most decks would rather go for a lower-costed card to fulfill this purpose (such as Bloodthrone Vampire. Usually the point isn't to make a huge creature, but to get the abilities that trigger when creatures die or get put into the graveyard.

209132: Phyrexian Arena.author: justicarphaeton
209132: Phyrexian Arena.text_parsed:
So why are Urza and Gerrard fighting to the death in gladiatorial combat? storywise, i mean.

I love this card. I love the sneaky feeling that you're being very evil when you get to draw two cards every turn and you see your opponent getting more and more worried wondering what's in all those cards you drew. I play it in a monoblack midrange with Korlash and Tendrils of Corruption; it ensures you have a lot of swamps and can keep gaining back a life buffer (and drawing into more Corrupts/Tendrils/Nighthawks, etc). Prolly not as good as Necropotence, but it's balanced.

Turn 1: Dark Ritual -> Arena is such an exciting play too.

209132: Phyrexian Arena.author: Wisdomseyes
209132: Phyrexian Arena.text_parsed:
I could go on and say how awesome this card is, and the reasons why, but why bother? we have several pages of it.

My issue with Dark confidant Vs this is that, although dark confidant is less mana for what can easily be considered the same effect, it is a creature and therefore all types of removal work on it rather than the abysmal amount of enchantment removal in modern.

I love this card. I love dark confidant as well. Sadly, 1 mana, and that one mana being black, makes a significant impact on the types of decks it can be put into.

4/5 stars, for being a great card with fantastic potential, but being outshined by his ravnica brother.

209132: Phyrexian Arena.text_parsed: NOT better than Dark Confidant. Bob has a 2/1 body that can beat or chump or trade if needed, comes out a turn earlier, for less B commitment, and can be more easily removed than an enchantment if the damage becomes too risky. Plus, most decks running him take an average of 1 damage each turn anyway. Not to say that Dark Confidant is necessarily better than this, but there's definitely not a clear winner.

209134: Slay.author: Pseudolias
209134: Slay.text_parsed:
The flavor text is silly. Yes this is a near-automatic +1: You use one card, Slay which is -1, get rid of a green creature, usually your opponent's, so we can say that's a +1, and it draws you a card, which is another +1. 0, the default, minus one, plus two, equals a positive one, making this an automatic +1 most of the time.
But in flavor, getting two minor victories in the war, even with just one strategy, doesn't kill the entire army. And knowing elf decks, you're gonna be facing down a BIIIIIG army. So how does the flavor text praise this card by saying only the numbers matter, when the elves are already likely to have that advantage as well as the other ones already mentioned? Or is this card trying to subtly poke fun at itself, maybe because somebody in R&D thought it was a poor card?

Either way, it's very good, at least against the right deck. Or with the right deck, for certain builds. 3.5/5.
209134: Slay.text_posted:
The flavor text is silly.  Yes this is a near-automatic +1:  You use one card, Slay which is -1, get rid of a green creature, usually your opponent's, so we can say that's a +1, and it draws you a card, which is another +1.  0, the default, minus one, plus two, equals a positive one, making this an automatic +1 most of the time.
But in flavor, getting two minor victories in the war, even with just one strategy, doesn't kill the entire army.  And knowing elf decks, you're gonna be facing down a BIIIIIG army.  So how does the flavor text praise this card by saying only the numbers matter, when the elves are already likely to have that advantage as well as the other ones already mentioned?  Or is this card trying to subtly poke fun at itself, maybe because somebody in R&D thought it was a poor card?

Either way, it's very good, at least against the right deck.  Or with the right deck, for certain builds.  3.5/5.

209142: Phyrexian Totem.author: allmighty_abacus
209142: Phyrexian Totem.text_parsed: this card misses the whole point of negator- you could drop it first turn with dark ritual and have an instant 5/5, and end the game in like 4 turns at worst. Now you have basically just a mana source for most of the game, until you can turn it into a creature without fear of it being dealt damage. With that drawback it needs to attack early, or it is ineffective.
209142: Phyrexian Totem.text_posted: this card misses the whole point of negator- you could drop it first turn with dark ritual and have an instant 5/5, and end the game in like 4 turns at worst. 209142: Phyrexian Totem.author: Bazooka99
209142: Phyrexian Totem.text_parsed:
@ROBRAM89: The "if it's a creature" clause would apply if a different effect turned the Totem into a creature momentarily. If my opponent plays March of the Machines, then plays Shock, dealing 2 damage to my 3/3 Phyrexian Totem, the triggered effect is placed on the stack requiring that I sacrifice 2 permanents if the Totem's a creature. While that's on the stack, I can Naturalize March of the Machines, turning my Totem back into a noncreature artifact. So even though it took 2 damage, by the time the triggered effect resolves, the Totem is no longer a creature, and I sacrifice no permanents.

Of course, this example is almost pointless, as there aren't many reasons I would wait for the damage from Shock to resolve before playing Naturalize (Rite of Passage, maybe?).
209142: Phyrexian Totem.text_posted:
@ROBRAM89: The "if it's a creature" clause would apply if a different effect turned the Totem into a creature momentarily. If my opponent plays [autocard]March of the Machines[/autocard], then plays [autocard]Shock[/autocard], dealing 2 damage to my 3/3 Phyrexian Totem, the triggered effect is placed on the stack requiring that I sacrifice 2 permanents if the Totem's a creature. While that's on the stack, I can [autocard]Naturalize[/autocard] March of the Machines, turning my Totem back into a noncreature artifact. So even though it took 2 damage, by the time the triggered effect resolves, the Totem is no longer a creature, and I sacrifice no permanents.

Of course, this example is almost pointless, as there aren't many reasons I would wait for the damage from Shock to resolve before playing Naturalize ([autocard]Rite of Passage[/autocard], maybe?).

209157: Gerrard Capashen.author: Mode
209157: Gerrard Capashen.text_parsed:
The artwork is perfect, but I agree with the others - the rest of this card doesn't do Gerrard justice.

He could have had first strike. His second ability could have cost with a once-a-turn-only restriction*.
Heck, he could have even gotten away with a cost of (indirectly upgrading his first ability).
(*Seriously, were they afraid would be abusable because you'd actually consider paying it twice once in a while?)

And since it's Gerrard, I would have seen nothing wrong with him having all of this instead.
Also he's part of Urza's bloodline project, which means even the storyline agrees that this would be reasonable.

209158: Coalition Relic.author: Kurraga
209158: Coalition Relic.text_parsed:
T1: Forest, Birds of Paradise
T2: Swamp, Coalition Relic, add charge counter
T3: Lotus cobra (using, mana from coalition and your swamp) play Mountain, add green, then play Explore, play another land, and play Harrow fixing your mana to one of each color, play a Maelstrom Archangel and a Clout of the Dominus, now you're out of mana and should have an empty hand, but if you went second and they have no fliers, you could attavk with your 7/7 flying haste shroud and play Coalition Victory and win. (Throw some Summoner's Pact in to find some of the cards named in the combo).

The 7th edition version was one of my first rares I was really happy to get. Certainly my first rare artifact creature. Man, he was a hammer back in the day. I ran him alongside twiddle and isochron scepter (nobody wanted to trade their voltaic keys...) in a blue control deck as my endgame. Never once had to pay the 8 life.

Time hasn't really been kind to him. Inkwell leviathan is now my preferred artifact creature endgame. He hits nearly as hard BUT never gets blocked what with spreading seas, and the shroud is amazing.

209160: Phyrexian Colossus.author: DarthParallax
209160: Phyrexian Colossus.text_parsed:
for random curiosity's sake, who would win---

Phyrexia, or Rainbow Brite? be serious. She IS 'just a little girl', BUT she has the advantage of
"Throwing Rainbows tends to make Evil Thingys die" in kid's stories--- I put her odds at a solid 50:50.
Either the Rainbows work or they don't, and the answer to that question tells you which way the one-sidedness goes. Definitely a one-sided fight though


Any takers?

Paleopaladin: I hate to break it to you, but New Phyrexia was a set that was kind of *meant* to upset and alienate the fans and players...think of it as the "Dark Knight" of MTG. In a fairer world, one where we were re-visiting an Invasion or Time Spiral-like era where the Phyrexians are going down? You might be right. But this time around, we were shown what happens when Phyrexia WINS.

What happens is we feel betrayed, violated, outgunned, and losing feels more like being murdered than dying in honorable combat. SHOULD they make cards like that? Debatable. Certainly when it's the result of unfortunate unforeseen interactions, it's regrettable, or when Development doesn't accurately predict the power level of Titans, that's regrettable too. And, yes, I feel for you that you don't like it. That you think it's unbalanced and overpowered. However, Wizards was fairly clear and open and honest with what they were doing. They sometimes make actual mistakes not predicting the ludicrous combos or whatever. But....Blightsteel Colossus was exactly what it was supposed to be, and they did it EXTREMELY on purpose.

Some Mythic Rare creatures were 'mistakes' that I like it when people argue about.

Blightsteel Colossus was not one of them. It was DESIGNED to make people like you cry. It was SUPPOSED to be a CRASS INSULT to Darksteel Colossus. Everything it was, was by intent. Blightsteel Colossus is to Darksteel Colossus as Uruk-Hai are to Elves: The perfection of the Orc, a twisted, cruel, hateful mockery made to destroy and defile. I feel sorry for you, but Phyrexia *wants* you to feel the way you do, so it can drink your delicious tears. :P Blightsteel was supposed to cause terror and despair and cries of agony.....AND IT SUCCEEDED!

Phyrexia, or Rainbow Brite?  be serious. She IS 'just a little girl', BUT she has the advantage of

Either the Rainbows work or they don't, and the answer to that question tells you which way the one-sidedness goes.  Definitely a one-sided fight though


Any takers?  

Paleopaladin: I hate to break it to you, but [i]New Phyrexia[/i] was a set that was kind of *meant* to upset and alienate the fans and players...think of it as the "Dark Knight" of MTG. In a fairer world, one where we were re-visiting an [i]Invasion or Time Spiral-like[/i] era where the Phyrexians are going down? You might be right. But this time around, we were shown what happens when Phyrexia WINS.

What happens is we feel betrayed, violated, outgunned, and losing feels more like being murdered than dying in honorable combat. SHOULD they make cards like that? Debatable. Certainly when it's the result of unfortunate unforeseen interactions, it's regrettable, or when Development doesn't accurately predict the power level of Titans, that's regrettable too. And, yes, I feel for you that you don't like it. That you think it's unbalanced and overpowered. However, Wizards was fairly clear and open and honest with what they were doing. They sometimes make actual mistakes not predicting the ludicrous combos or whatever. But....[autocard]Blightsteel Colossus[/autocard] was exactly what it was supposed to be, and they did it EXTREMELY on purpose. 

Some Mythic Rare creatures were 'mistakes' that I like it when people argue about. 

Blightsteel Colossus was not one of them. It was DESIGNED to make people like you cry. It was SUPPOSED to be a CRASS INSULT to Darksteel Colossus. Everything it was, was by intent. Blightsteel Colossus is to Darksteel Colossus as Uruk-Hai are to Elves: The perfection of the Orc, a twisted, cruel, hateful mockery made to destroy and defile. I feel sorry for you, but Phyrexia *wants* you to feel the way you do, so it can drink your delicious tears. :P Blightsteel was supposed to cause terror and despair and cries of agony.....AND IT SUCCEEDED!

209161: Sanguine Guard.author: Wanderer25
209161: Sanguine Guard.text_parsed:
This seems to be an improved version of Lim-Dûl's High Guard. It has one more toughness, but the always-relevant zombie creature type is what sets this apart from the earlier guard. That and this has to be my favorite Phyrexian flavor text. I first saw it when Urza Block came out, and it's one of the few flavor texts that really stuck with me. For some reason I always remembered it as "Thy filigree gaze", which would've fit more with the "demonic ***ure" flavor, but oh well.

Anyway, it's still a solid blocker with two highly relevant creature types. You can run him with Haakon, Stromgald Scourge or with Death Baron. I give him 3.5 for that, but the stellar flavor earns him an extra star from me. 4.5/5

EDIT: S-C-R-I-P-Ture. Seriously Gatherer?? What's wrong with the word scrip t?

210133: Carrion Feeder.author: Diachronos
210133: Carrion Feeder.text_parsed:
Carrion Feeder becomes absolutely ridiculous with the Zombie tribal base that the Innistrad block brought to the table.

The most obvious one is Gravecrawler, since he can be played from the graveyard as many times as you have black mana... or as many times as you want if you have Rooftop Storm on the field.

Then there are all of the ways to get Zombie tokens, like Army of the Damned. And Endless Ranks of the Dead; the opponent will have to choose between blocking Carrion Feeder or letting him through, and either way the little corpse is going to get HUGE.

Reassembling Skeleton is the obvious combo here, though Festering Goblin works well too. But if you're willing to splash white, you get can get double duty out of the sacrifice with Unruly Mob. 210133: Carrion Feeder.author: El_Pared
210133: Carrion Feeder.text_parsed:
back in the day there was somewhat of an argument: Carrion Feeder, or Nantuko Husk?

It seems that now our favorite little corpse eater is still the best. So many uses for him: Sack a Gravecrawler and have it come back for more good eats, sack a Festering Goblin for easy 1 toughness removal, eat your Graveborn Muse when she starts getting our of control, even sack your Lord of the Undead out from under a pesky Lightning Helix and ruin someone's day.

of course, Husk can do all those things too, but you know what he can't do? Keep his buffs after he eats things. sure you can dodge that lightning helix, but you can't swing for +1 the next turn.

Carrion Feeder, as someone else already said, is great because your opponent must play around it or it or be destroyed

210134: Phyrexian Broodlings.text_parsed:
This is a pretty solid card but like its fellows it's considerably worse after the rules change. It used to be you could just nom up anything that would have died in combat after it dealt damage.

Compare with carrion feeder, which can do the same but for free. I'd say the feeder is better overall because the activation cost on stuff like this means your opponent doesn't have to play around it quite so much.

210137: Worn Powerstone.author: donjohnson
210137: Worn Powerstone.text_parsed:
Anyone who thinks this card is aweful simply hasnt used it properly and probably doesnt understand that getting into the game a full turn earlier can mean winning or losing. One turn is all it takes to lose, as real players already know.

The powerstone is MUCH better because you get into the game a full turn earlier, costing 3 instead of 4, and you get the SAME 2 colorless as either of those others give.
It blows thran dynamo and sisay's ring away because you end up being able to use it one full turn earlier than either of those. With thran dynamo and sisay's ring youre blowing 4 mana on turn four so its turn 5 before you even get to use it with any effectiveness.
With the worn powerstone you play turn 3 so on turn 4 you have 6 mana available.

Basalt Monolith was fine in its day, but it stinks compared to the Worn Powerstone quite frankly, because you get to use it once and then its dead weight the rest of the game, unless of course youre the type who loves throwing 3 mana away every other turn.
Grim monolith is good for one turn of acceleration, then like the Basalt, is completely useless costing even more (4 mana) to untap. Again a card for players who love throwing mana way every other turn. The same goes for Mana Vault.

Mana Crypt is an excellent card if you trust leaving yourself to the odds of a coin toss.

Sol Ring blows all other acceleration out of the water...but thats why its restricted ;)

210138: Living Death.author: blurrymadness
210138: Living Death.text_parsed:
most of the time this is the best mass-reanimate. Living End does well in multicolored (grixis style for instant speed removal of suspend counters from Rift Elemental, Clockspinning etc..) and also for things that abuse 0-cost cards (such as panoptic mirror)

That said, Living Death does the same thing but is much easier to use. It makes my Demon Tribal deck not only playable, but decent. Currently I use a mix of Living Death, Living End and maybe Twilight's Call/Pyhrric Revival.

Using dredge, targeted discard, putrid imp etc, I can usually get a few demons out, and once I get a Hellcarver things get AWESOME. Imagine casting one of these a turn ago, attacking with a whole bunch of creatures (which all get sacced) reanimating them and casting another 1-2 for free. That's what that deck does. Spectacularly huge demon battles come out (even IF half of them sacrifice eachother/can't pay upkeep/etc..)

210138: Living Death.author: The_Murderauder
210138: Living Death.text_parsed:
@07mak: I don't really understand how this combos with the plaguelord. So, first, you sac all your creatures to the plaguelord to kill their creatures, then you cast this, and you get all your creatures back, sure, but so do they, including the ones you just killed.
This would combo with basically ANY other sac outlet (Goblin Bombardment WUT WUT) but since the plaguelord specifically kills creatures, it actually sucks with this card, because it just undoes all your work.

Unless you mean that you should just cast this with plaguelord+others in your graveyard, get them all back, THEN sac your dudes to kill the creatures they might have, but in that case it's no better than any random boardwipe, since you both end up with few/no creatures.

210139: Tendrils of Corruption.author: Keiya

@BiOhyBr: Not in all cases. Corrupt can deal damage to players as well, which usually results in it being a better late-game card when you need to finish your opponent.

That said, I find it slightly amusing that while the legal target options are about the only difference between the two cards function-wise (Aside from mana costs and one being an Instant and the other a Sorcery), the cards explain their effects so differently.

210139: Tendrils of Corruption.author: JaxsonBateman
210139: Tendrils of Corruption.text_parsed: The lifegain is pretty significant, and in a deck with enough swamps (or reliable Urborg) it's worth the 2 mana extra over more reliable kill spells like Go for the Throat. I personally run it in a very-creature-light MBC deck, and it helps keep me alive until my card advantage engines take over and win the game.

210139: Tendrils of Corruption.author: Aremath
210139: Tendrils of Corruption.text_parsed:
@Keiya: If you look at the original printing (Time Spiral), the flavor text is about some dark swamp monster thing, just like the flavor text on all printings of Corrupt. So the differences are not all that great.

I use it in my Toshiro Umezawa EDH deck. For 8 mana I can often kill two things and gain 16 life. At that point the lifegain becomes relevant. Overall, the best thing about this card is instant speed. Almost all good killspells are instant speed, and cost 3 or less. While this one is a little too expensive, the attached lifegain is often great. Can work in multicolor decks thanks to shocklands.

4/5

210558: Verduran Emissary.author: Kirbster
210558: Verduran Emissary.text_parsed:
Not a bad card, but it compares rather unfavourably to the likes of Tin Street Hooligan and Vithian Renegades.

This card also has the unique privilege of being the only card illustrated by the notoriously bad fantasy artist, Alton Lawson. This picture isn't even that bad, compared to his other works, but... look him up if you don't believe me.
